drugs: Sulfur Hexafluoride Lipid Type A Microspheres

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Sulfur Hexafluoride Lipid Type A Microspheres

sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Echocardiography; Adjunct: 2 mL IV followed by a 5-mL NS flush; may administer a second 2-mL IV dose followed by a 5-mL NS flush during the same imaging session to prolong image enhancement

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Powder for Suspension)
Although uncommon, serious cardiopulmonary reactions with fatalities have occurred during or following the injection of ultrasound contrast agents, including sulfur hexafluoride lipid type A microspheres. Most reactions occur within 30 minutes of administration. Assess all patients for conditions that preclude administration and have resuscitation equipment and trained personnel available.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• do not administer by intra-arterial injection
  • history of hypersensitivity reactions to sulfur hexafluoride lipid microsphere or any product components
  • right-to-left, bidirectional, or transient right-to-left cardiac shunts

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- serious cardiopulmonary reactions with fatalities have occurred during or following injection; typically occur within 30 minutes of administration; assess patient for conditions that preclude administration and have resuscitation equipment available
  • Cardiovascular:
  • -- unstable cardiopulmonary conditions (eg, acute myocardial infarction, acute coronary artery syndromes, worsening or unstable congestive heart failure, or serious ventricular arrhythmias) may increase risk for serious cardiopulmonary reactions; monitoring recommended
  • -- systemic embolization with tissue ischemia may occur in patients with right-to-left, bidirectional, or transient right-to-left cardiac shunts
  • -- ventricular arrhythmias may occur if high ultrasound mechanical index values cause cavitation or rupture of microspheres, or with end-systolic triggering with high mechanical indices
  • Immunologic:
  • -- anaphylactoid reactions (eg, skin erythema, rash, urticaria, flushing, throat tightness, dyspnea, or anaphylactic shock) have been reported, even in patients with no history of prior exposure
  • Neurologic:
  • -- loss of consciousness and convulsions have been reported with ultrasound contrast agents
  • Respiratory:
  • -- fatal respiratory arrest, dyspnea, hypoxia, respiratory distress, stridor, and wheezing have been reported with ultrasound contrast agents

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (0.6%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (0.9%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac arrest, Chest pain (0.2%), Shock, Syncope, Ventricular fibrillation, Ventricular tachycardia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Respiratory:Respiratory arrest

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Sulfur hexafluoride lipid microspheres consist of a phospholipid monolayer outer shell encasing a core of sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas. Ultrasound signals are reflected from the interface between the microspheres and the local tissues because microspheres within the blood have a lower acoustic impedance than the surrounding tissue.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, IV: 1 to 2 minutes, healthy volunteers: (sulfur hexafluoride gas component)
  • Tmax, IV, pulmonary impairment: 1 to 4 minutes (sulfur hexafluoride gas component)

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Lungs: Minimal transformation (sulfur hexafluoride gas component)

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono: Not measurable at recommended dose (sulfur hexafluoride gas component)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute with provided 5 mL NS injection and shake vigorously for 20 seconds to completely dissolve into homogenous white milky liquid; store at room temperature and use reconstituted solution within 3 hours
  • if not used immediately after reconstitution, before withdrawing dose, shake vial to resuspend microbubbles; administer immediately after drawing into syringe
  • administer as an IV bolus injection and follow with a 5 mL flush of NS
  • discard remainder

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• satisfactory ultrasound imaging to opacify the left ventricular chamber and to improve the delineation of the left ventricular endocardial border may indicate efficacy
  • acute cardiopulmonary reactions

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Side effects may include headache, nausea, dysgeusia, chest discomfort, injection site pain, or injection site warmth.
